Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech by creating an imbalance of power between citizens.
Excessive fines will have a chilling effect on open discussions and freedom of speech.
Determining what is true or false is challenging due to constantly emerging information.
The bill's reliance on industry bodies for code development could lead to anti-competitive practices.
The extraterritorial application of the bill is unworkable and unfair for foreign digital services.
The bill infringes on constitutional freedoms, particularly the freedom of political communication.
The bill poses threats to digital platform providers and users through reputational damage and financial penalties.
Notable Quotes: By creating two classes of citizens, with some having the power to spread information deemed false or misleading and others being restricted, the bill establishes an imbalance of power.
The excessive fines imposed by the bill have a chilling effect on freedom of speech.
The task of accurately determining what is true or false is an impossible one.
The bill's reliance on industry bodies to develop codes of conduct is deeply flawed.
The bill's infringements on constitutional freedoms, specifically the freedom of political communication, further add to its flawed nature.
